gurmukhi: ijm icngwrI Agn kI igrq sGn bn mwih ]
transliteration: Jim Chingadriagad Kigirat Saghan Ban Maah(i)||
translation: “The manner in which only a spark of fire, falling down, grows immensely in stature;

gurmukhi: AiDk qnk qy hoq hY iqm idjbr nr nwih ]12]
transliteration: Adhik Tanak Te Hot Hai Tim Dijbar Nar Naah(i)||12||
translation: “Likewise this small-sized Brahmin is not a man.”12.

gurmukhi: hs BUpq ieh bwq bKwnI ] sunhu su`kR qum bwq nw jwnI ]
transliteration: Has Bhoopat Eh Baat Bakhaanee|| Sounoh Soukkra Toum Baat Naa Jaanee||
translation: The king Bali, laughingly, said these words to Shukracharya: “O Shukracharya ! You are not comprehending it, I shall not regain such an occasion,

gurmukhi: Puin ieh smo sBo Cl jYhY ] hir so Pyir n iB`Ck AYhY ]13]
transliteration: Phoun(i) Eh Samo Sabho Chhal Jaihai|| Har(i) So Pher(i) Na Bhichchhak Aihai||13||
translation: “Because I shall not be able to get such a God-like beggar again.”13.

gurmukhi: mn mih bwq iehY TihrweI ] mn mo DrI n iksU bqweI ]
transliteration: Man Maih Baat Ihai Thaihraaee|| Man Mo Dharina Kisoo Bataaee||
translation: The King decided this general notion in his mind, but perceptibly he did not divulge it to anyone.

gurmukhi: BiRq qy mwNg kmMfl eysw ] lgXo dwn iqh dyn nrysw ]14]
transliteration: Bhrit Te Maan Kamanndal Esaa|| Lagyo Daan Tih Den Daresaa||14||
translation: He asked the medicant to give his pot, in order to enact such a base deed.14.

gurmukhi: su`kR bwq mn mo pihcwnI ] Byd n lhq BUp AigAwnI ]
transliteration: Soukkra Baat Man Mo Paihchaanee|| Bhed Na Lahat Bhoop Agiaanee||
translation: Shukracharya understood the notion of the mind of the King, but the ignorant King could not comprehend it.

gurmukhi: Dwr mkr ky jwr srUpw ] pYiTXo m`D kmMfl BUpw ]15]
transliteration: Dhaar Maker Ke Jaar Daroopaa|| Paithiyo Maddh Kamanndal Bhoopaa||15||
translation: Shukracharya transformed himself into a small fish and seated himself in the mendicant’s pot.15.

gurmukhi: niRpbr pwn surwhI leI ] dwn smY idjbr kI BeI ]
transliteration: Nriphar Paan Suraahilaee|| Daan Samai Dijbar Kibhaee||
translation: The King took the mendicant’s pot in his hand and the time forgiving alms to the Brahmin arrived.
